ParentCompanyName: Freeport Liquid Natural Gas Development, LP

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
EXECUTIVE SUMMARY 2018 RISK MANAGEMENT PROGRAM UPDATE

A Risk Management Program has been implemented at the Freeport Liquid Natural Gas (LNG), Oyster Creek, Texas natural gas Pretreatment Facility (PTF) to reduce the risk of accidental releases of hazardous materials. This Risk Management Plan summarizes the management, administrative, procedural and technological controls that work together to minimize the risk of hazardous chemical releases to the community.



FREEPORT LNG POLICIES FOR ENVIRONMENT, HEALTH AND SAFETY

Risk management and safety are core principles at Freeport LNG. Freeport LNG is committed to conducting its operations in a safe, responsible manner and to reduce risks to health and the environment. Commitment to environment, health and safety (EHS) starts with the CEO. Senior management routinely dedicates time to review EHS matters. Emphasis on safety is carried through to the facility level, where the Production Manager and the Safety Department regularly review safety performance, take corrective actions and strive for continuous improvement. Freeport LNG's EHS programs include policies, procedures, standards, and guidance materials designed to fulfill Freeport LNG's commitment to environment, health and safety. These materials include Risk Management Program guidance to assist our facilities to prevent and/or reduce the risk of accidents. Should an accidental hazardous substance release occur, we also have implemented a comprehensive Emergency Response Program to promptly respond, address, and minimize the consequences of the release.



FACILITY IDENTIFICATION AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES IN COVERED PROCESSES

The Freeport LNG natural gas pretreatment facility is located at 2363 CR 690, Oyster Creek, Texas. The facility pretreats natural gas to remove carbon dioxide (CO2), sulfur compounds, water, mercury, and heavy hydrocarbons. ees are informed of changes to the facility's Emergency Response Plan.



PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

Chemical safety has been a part of the working culture at the facility during the pre-start up activities such as training and procedure development. Chemical exposure risks to employees and the public have been emphasized through ongoing internal risk reduction efforts as well as adherence to regulatory requirements. Ongoing improvements to the safety program will include implementation of behavior based safety. Facility improvements addressing newly recognized safety issues will be incorporated into the existing safety program through the use of the facility's Management of Change Program.
